results.title: The Grannies
results.creator_credit: Luke Neher, Marie Foulston and Nick Murray
results.credit_line:
Music by Sam Gill and Luke Neher. Sound design by Sam Gill. Starring Kalonica Quigley, Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, and friends. Voiceover is excerpted from an interview originally for P3 Spel, conducted by Angelica Norgren.

Visuals captured from Red Dead Redemption 2
Rockstar Games, USA, 2018

Courtesy Marie Foulston
results.brief_description:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.
By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game world itself were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player becomes a set of artistic possibilities. Rather than focusing on the game’s objectives, their adventures beyond the map, and their reflections on them, are oriented around artistic inquiry, playfulness and friendship.
The unexpected terrain and landmarks the grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – – not because they help direct players towards a goal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Luke Neher, Marie Foulston and Nick Murray
results.description:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.

By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player piques curiosity about the materiality of the game’s environmental design. Textures collide at strange angles, revealing layers that are meant to be obscured. A strange grey cube hangs on the sky, monumental in its lack of finish and finesse compared to the landscape around it.

The unexpected terrain and landmarks The Grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – not because they help direct players towards a goal.

These artists’ explorations are not just a way to escape the game’s map, but to escape the game’s expectations of how a player should act, and its methods of anticipating their actions.

results.title: Landmarks
results.credit_line:
Visuals captured by The Grannies from Red Dead Redemption 2
Rockstar Games, USA, 2018
Text by Kalonica Quigley
results.brief_description:
In their time out of bounds, The Grannies captured many landmarks and locations through Red Dead Redemption 2’s photography system.
Unlike many big-budget videogames, Red Dead Redemption 2 doesn’t offer a ‘photo mode’ that allows players to manipulate the time of day and camera angle. Instead, it operates more or less like a real-world camera, with each photo taken from the character’s perspective.
Ian MacLarty described lining up the perfect shot as ‘like a game in itself’, requiring a lifelike combination of precision and luck to capture the perfect angle and quality of light.
These photos, so lovingly framed and shot, have a radical undertone. Their explorations could be considered a kind of psychogeography – an artistic practice that involved exploring urban environments to emphasise personal responses to place, rather than focusing on productivity or purpose.
Similarly, the images captured here showcase The Grannies’ emotional, playful relationship with digital space that contradicts the intended design of the game.
Since they were taken, Red Dead Redemption 2 has been updated to stop players from travelling outside the map. Still, these images remain, a reminder of the freedom that curiosity and exploration can offer.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 - Indigo
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Antartica, Future, Wake up Return 2 Heart, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Air Fiction (Andy Taylor), Steve Law (Zen Paradox), Tom Cia, Derek ‘Chill’ Shiel and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: anywhere and here
results.credit_line:
Ian Burns
mixed media installation
ACMI Collection
results.brief_description:
‘anywhere and here’ is a suite of five interconnected kinetic sculptures which generate their own real-time video. It specifically explores the road movie genre, summoning familiar visions of the empty landscape, the wide open road and the car-in-motion, to destabilise powerful cinematic clichés.

‘anywhere and here’ was commissioned by ACMI and was exhibited at ACMI as “Ian Burns: In the Telling” in 2012-13.

Burns adapts existing appliances and domestic items and gives them new functions within his sculptures. This work draws meaning from the contrast between the projected image and the machinery out of which it is made.

The five sculptures that make up this work are linked via a video control system constructed by Burns and designed to switch between each of the structures at random. The images that are produced by the sculptures are projected onto the wall for the audience to view. Each scene generates its own live soundtrack. Burns has hacked an electronic keyboard to plunk out a simple music track. The keyboard becomes an integral part of the sculpture.

A shot of the moon suspended over water is based around a glass top table. The resulting optic effect simulates water movement and sparkle. A strip of plywood simulates the sky at dusk, while the moon is created by the projection of light through a hole in the wood.

On one end of a folding table the effect of a smoking chimney is generated using a plastic salad bowl with a LED light inside shining through a slit cut in the backing of a picture frame. The view from the camera is across a roll of hobby store brick print paper.

On the other end of the folding table, to simulate a high zoom shot of a plane passing overhead, Burns rotates a party store plastic salad bowl while a LED light inside the bowl generates the cloud effect. A fan usually used as a cooling device for a computer, generates the sound of the jet and shakes the camera to simulate the zoom effect on a hand-held camera.

A black vinyl chair has been stripped of all its vinyl until only a narrowing strip remains with slots cut out of it. The camera view of this under a red light gives it the look of a remote roadway in dry country.

The shot in close-up of a wheel with the white stripes of the road whizzing past is a road movie cliché. The sculpture is constructed out of an actual car wheel on a treadmill and a camera positioned to catch a cinematic view of the action.

The fifth sculpture comprises the central electronic system that guides the work as a whole.

results.title: Looking after Yaimini
results.creator_credit: Larry Zetlin, Ruth Berry and Gulliver Film Productions
results.brief_description: A comprehensive and sympathetic portrayal of an Aboriginal family living in an outstation or homelands situation in Central Arnhem Land, Northern Territory. Subtitled.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Larry Zetlin, Ruth Berry and Gulliver Film Productions

results.title: Behind the mountain
results.brief_description: This collaborative video installation presents floor projections in randomly scattered blank cardboard boxes, encased within the borders of each the image of a moving figure of a mixed Aboriginal demographic, confined and enclosed in the space through the image size. The viewer moves in amongst and interacts with these images, their shadow visible over the image as they lean to look into each box. The figures within, dancers filmed from the Bangarra Dance Company, contort and rotate in the limits of the space, pulling inwards and pushing outwards, visually and spatially engaging in the historical and contemporary forces which construct and confine the Aboriginal body. In interaction with these images the use of a surround sound composite creates an aural journey that evokes pulsing electrical currents in a storage space, interrupted sporadically by the sound of tearing packing tape and a strong bass sound from below each box which creates a sensorial engagement with the movement in the images within.

production_dates.notes: 'behind the mountains' is a commission for the ACMI and NGV exhibition 2004

results.title: Infected
results.material_description: video, circular screen, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Infected is a projected video installation about the nature of the physical body in the context of future technological possibilities, seen through dance and digitally manipulated imagery. The new bio-engineered body is still a sexual, stark, brutal, organic, pounding bloody system with ripping tendons. It is beautiful and repulsive, indulgent, curious, emotional, un/controlled, breeding, changing.

Gina Czarnecki is an artist originating from the UK whose films and installations have been exhibited widely across the UK and around the world. Infected continues her work around the visceral, biological and emotive body and its politics in relation to new technologies.

This video is made in collaboration with Iona Kewney, a Glasgow-based dance artist. It features a specially commissioned score by Fennesz, whose computer-manipulations of sounds derived from guitar and other acoustic sources have won him worldwide acclaim as one of the most innovative and important artists working in electronic music.

Gina Czarnecki is an artist originating from the UK whose films and installations have been exhibited widely across the UK and around the world. Infected continues her work around the visceral, biological and emotive body and its politics in relation to new technologies.

This video is made in collaboration with Iona Kewney, a Glasgow-based dance artist. It features a specially commissioned score by Fennesz, whose computer-manipulations of sounds derived from guitar and other acoustic sources have won him worldwide acclaim as one of the most innovative and important artists working in electronic music.
description_for_label:
Infected is a projected video installation about the nature of the physical body in the context of future technological possibilities, seen through dance and digitally manipulated imagery. The new bio-engineered body is still a sexual, stark, brutal, organic, pounding bloody system with ripping tendons. It is beautiful and repulsive, indulgent, curious, emotional, un/controlled, breeding, changing.

Gina Czarnecki is an artist originating from the UK whose films and installations have been exhibited widely across the UK and around the world. Infected continues her work around the visceral, biological and emotive body and its politics in relation to new technologies.

This video is made in collaboration with Iona Kewney, a Glasgow-based dance artist. It features a specially commissioned score by Fennesz, whose computer-manipulations of sounds derived from guitar and other acoustic sources have won him worldwide acclaim as one of the most innovative and important artists working in electronic music.

results.title: acmipark
results.material_description: interactive software, computers, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
acmipark is multiplayer virtual world. Created by selectparks (artists Julian Oliver, Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell), it was designed to extend the physical spaces of the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) at Melbourne’s Federation Square into the realms of virtual space. It was produced using a game engine as its base, and worked up from the real architectural designs produced for Federation Square by Lab Architecture Studio.

Designed as a soundpark, it is a musical instrument which can be played collectively, and, like Federation Square itself, it was envisaged as a kind of public space waiting for a community to define its meaning.

It was conceived as an experiment in the design of a virtual public space. It is an embodiment of the idea that we are moving our public space into the realm of the virtual. By using a model of a real world public space combined with the collaborative possibilities of the soundpark and the kinaesthetic pleasures of moving through a beautiful virtual place, selectparks hoped to build upon traditional concepts of ‘public’ places.

[Source: Helen Stuckey, 2006 https://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1561/1476 last accessed 20/10/2020]

results.title: Spitfire 123
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The third in an ongoing six-part series collectively titled ‘From the Darwin Translations’. This series, like Jones’ previous projects, shifts between installation, video, and performance, in an exploration of human (sexual) attraction. The installation spans two rooms, one with a large screen and another with three video monitors. The monitor room shows a more meditative, transitional space, ‘poppy fields’; a repeating image series of swaying poppies, accompanied by the rustle of wind, bird song and insect noises and interrupted now and then by the roar of airplanes flying overhead. The large screen in the other room presents, ‘Spitfire’, showing shots from the cockpit of the legendary World War II fighter plane, accompanied by engine-sounds, dramatic computerized noises and oscillating-music, as well as whispering voices. Sky and land spiral, falter, and blur as intimate fantasies are imparted. Thus the result is fragmented and disorientating. The position of the audience shifts between that of voyeur and that of participant. She threatens to undo you with the romance of memory, aeroplanes and youth; you have to look, listen and feel.
